Sri  Lanka  has  91,803  kilometers  (km)  of  roads,  comprising  11,650  km  of  national 
highways maintained by the Road Development Authority (RDA); 15,494 km of roads (classes 
C, D, and E) maintained by provincial councils; and 64,659 km of unclassified roads maintained 
by local authorities. The public sector retains most of the responsibilities for providing national 
highways and other roads. 
 
While Sri Lanka’s road network is extensive, most roads were built more than 50 years 
4. 
ago.  Road  maintenance,  rehabilitation,  and  new  construction  have  not  kept  abreast  with  the 
rapid  growth  in  demand  for  transport.  Traffic  levels  now  exceed  the  design  capacity of many 
roads.  Uncontrolled  roadside  development  has  also  reduced  the  network’s  capacity.  Due  to 
neglect of road maintenance, national, provincial, and rural road conditions are poor. All of this 
raises road-user costs, makes roads unsafe, and lowers the quality and frequency of transport 
services.  Inefficient  transport  has  constrained  economic  expansion  and  poverty  reduction. 
Upgrading the road sector’s overall performance is vital to improve the returns and sustainability 
of investments, contribute to growth of a wide range of other economic activities that make use 
of road transport, and help reduce poverty.

Implementation  of  ADB-assisted  road  projects  in  Sri  Lanka  have  been  delayed  due 
mainly to (i) cumbersome government procurement procedures, affecting projects in all sectors; 
(ii) lack of institutional capacity in RDA for preconstruction and for construction supervision; and 
(iii)  lack  of  capacity  and  inexperience  of  the  domestic  private  sector  in  road  construction  and 
engineering  and  related  services.  Such  weaknesses  include  late  appointment of the technical 
evaluation  committee  (TEC),  low  quality  of  TEC  reports,  delayed  finalization  of  contract 
documents, delayed approval by Cabinet Appointed Tender Boards and the Ministry of Tender 
Boards, and slow implementation of land acquisition and resettlement (LAR).  
 
11.  With  ADB  TA,7  the  Government  simplified  its  procurement  procedures  for  externally 
funded projects, introduced a system of monitoring procurement performance, and established 
the  Procurement  Support  Bureau  in  the  Ministry  of  Finance,  which  is  reducing  the  time  for 
procurement and increasing transparency. Weaknesses of LAR implementation under previous 
loans  have  been  improved  under  the  ADB  TAs,8  incorporating  experience  from  the  Southern 
Transport  Development  Project.  RSDP (footnote 5)’s recent progress shows that reforms are 
achieving their targets: (i)  the Road Construction and Development Company, owned by RDA, 
was closed at the end of January 2004; (ii) SLRs1 billion of work contracts were awarded to 20 
private  contractors  in  2003;  (iii)  reengineering  of  RDA  is  under  way,  e.g.,  a  maintenance 
management unit has been established; and (iv) a road fund was established in 2003 to support 
the  financing  of  road  maintenance  on  a  sustainable  basis.  The  capacity  of  provincial  road 
development authorities has also been strengthened through an ongoing program financed by 
ADB and Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC)9. 
 
12. 
A  lesson  is  that  institutional  reforms  need  to  be  comprehensive  but  gradual  and 
sustained  if  they  are  to  produce  lasting  improvements  (footnote  4).  This  is  difficult  to  achieve 
through a single project. The programmatic approach brings together ADB’s next interventions 
for  the  road  sector,  creating  the  opportunity  to  link  financing  of  successive  projects  to 
implementation  of  a  common  medium-term  reform  agenda.  Another  lesson  learned  from 
procedural delays in project preparation is that  up-front project activities, such as environmental 
clearances and LAR, need to be completed before the investment loan is contracted, because 
these kinds of activity often delay disbursement of approved investment loans. Preconstruction
